text: Hey all, I'd love to know what your editorial process looks like for long-form pieces. Do editors touch things at multiple stages of the writing process? Just the end? I was inspired by this post and curious to hear other content teams' approach: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/how-to-write-a-blog-post-outline/>. Bonus if your team is on the larger side and editors are responsible for multiple writers.

elements.text: Hey all, I'd love to know what your editorial process looks like for long-form pieces. Do editors touch things at multiple stages of the writing process? Just the end? I was inspired by this post and curious to hear other content teams' approach:
. Bonus if your team is on the larger side and editors are responsible for multiple writers.

text: This message was deleted.

Our primary editor (who manages about 6 writers’ work) does the initial outline and then edits the piece at the end. We tried having different people outline, then edit, but it always ended up adding unnecessary complications.

elements.text: Our primary editor (who manages about 6 writers’ work) does the initial outline and then edits the piece at the end. We tried having different people outline, then edit, but it always ended up adding unnecessary complications.

text: our team is only a few people at the moment, and I’m the only content person. But My manager and I cooperate to craft an outline and we invite the rest of the marketing team to comment and provide feedback before going into the writing stage. for the writing stage, we only restrict edits to myself and a core group of marketing folks before publishing

text: Hi! Does anyone have examples of effective employee spotlight style content? We have done a few interviews with team members (for a manufacturing company) but I’m wondering if there are ways to boost engagement with these types of behind-the-scenes posts. Ultimately I want to humanize the brand because—let’s face it—manufacturing can be pretty dry.

elements.text: Hi! Does anyone have examples of effective employee spotlight style content? We have done a few interviews with team members (for a manufacturing company) but I’m wondering if there are ways to boost engagement with these types of behind-the-scenes posts. Ultimately I want to humanize the brand because—let’s face it—manufacturing can be pretty dry.

text: So, for boosting a spotlight internally once you've shared it... how many people does the company have and what is the official goal/purpose of the spotlights? Is the intent to humanize the brand internally or externally? Or both?

elements.text: So, for boosting a spotlight internally once you've shared it... how many people does the company have and what is the official goal/purpose of the spotlights? Is the intent to humanize the brand internally or externally? Or both?

text: If internally (assuming the goal is to build internally morale/community ) - I'd recommend sharing via your intercomm channels by highlighting the person in your weekly roundup of information or a message from someone "fancy".

elements.text: If internally (assuming the goal is to build internally morale/community ) - I'd recommend sharing via your intercomm channels by highlighting the person in your weekly roundup of information or a message from someone "fancy".

text: If externally, do you have a way you can highlight your employees AND your collaborators/suppliers employees? So making it an industry spotlight? That way you're building community with your suppliers too - which could lead to stronger partnerships.

elements.text: If externally, do you have a way you can highlight your employees AND your collaborators/suppliers employees? So making it an industry spotlight? That way you're building community with your suppliers too - which could lead to stronger partnerships.

text: As for sharing with the general public... hmmm. I'd make a fun branded post and share it in stories first, using the question feature, getting people to answer a silly question about the person and their hobbies, and then revealing the answer in a post in the feed with a link to the spotlight. That may sound silly - but it's worked in the past. Not AMAZING, but it did garner some engagement and comments.

elements.text: As for sharing with the general public... hmmm. text: I'm on team editor touches multiple times. Even if it's just connection and encouragement. I've found people are more engaged and excited about a piece if they're proud of the people in the process to create it. It also gives me the chance to help coach and support writers as they actively work on hurdles in their craft.

elements.text: I'm on team editor touches multiple times. Even if it's just connection and encouragement. text:
The touch points I've used recently are:
*Content Bank* - deciding which articles to pursue (upvoting). _Editor: collaborative engagement_
*KickOff Call* - to calibrate on the goals of the post and content notes we need to hit (especially intentions!). _Editor: strong engagement_
*Outline* - (this one is via airstory or something like that). _Editor: strong engagement_
*Research* - this one for my team is hivemind - where we all share research we've found - but the writer is the primary researcher - everyone else is just contributing if they have something to share. _Editor: minimal engagement_
*Rough Draft* - checking for content gaps, goals, and story flow. _Editor: strong engagement_
*Final proof* _-_ grammar, keywords, goals, etc. _Editor: strong engagement_
*Post Launch Debrief* - checking analytics, reception, social engagement, etc. _Editor: strong engagement_

Editor: strong engagement

text: Recently, I worked in the health & fitness industry. We posted weekly highlights about community partners (other businesses we were collaborating with), members, and employees. These were just social media posts with an interesting fact/quote from the person/brand. The employee & member posts got way more engagement than any of other posts, especially the employee highlights. We'd simply share a bit about the employee & a photo, and everyone ate them up. Employee highlights would regularly get about 50 likes and many comments, whereas other regular posts would get a lot less usually with few comments. Helps to also encourage employees to engage. Hope this helps at all!

elements.text: Recently, I worked in the health & fitness industry. We posted weekly highlights about community partners (other businesses we were collaborating with), members, and employees. The employee & member posts got way more engagement than any of other posts, especially the employee highlights. We'd simply share a bit about the employee & a photo, and everyone ate them up. Employee highlights would regularly get about 50 likes and many comments, whereas other regular posts would get a lot less usually with few comments. Helps to also encourage employees to engage. Hope this helps at all!

text:
Watch out...content person doing social media :warning:

Our new social person starts at the end of the month...in the meantime, has anyone seen Twitter's new "professional profiles"? If you're a b2b brand, any benefit in these? It looks like they're more for retail, with the hours/location focus. But my CEO got all excited, so I wanted to check. Any thoughts?

<https://business.twitter.com/en/campaign/professional-profiles.html>

text: Yep, it's purely for retail/local businesses. For online B2B brands, displaying that info won't help in anyway.

text:
Heyo folks, we're preparing the most extensive directory of strategies and guides for B2B SaaS content marketing you can find on the web. Is there anything particular you would like to see inside? Here are some of the current topics:

• Advantages of doing SaaS Content Marketing (Short Blog Post)
• ICP Research for Content Marketing Purposes and finding a content-market fit
• Types of SaaS Content Marketing Strategies you can use
• How to create a content marketing plan for saas?
• What type of SaaS content marketing content should you create (Based on your stage)?
• How to do KW research for SaaS content marketing
• How to write content for SaaS Content Marketing
• How to distribute your SaaS content?
• How to optimize SaaS articles for conversions (How to improve saas content marketing visitor to user signup conversion rate)
• Agency or In-house content marketing team?
• How to choose the right saas content marketing agency?
• How to build and scale a content marketing team?
• How to build saas content marketing processes?
For the context - the strategies and guides we write will be based on 700+ articles we wrote during the last 2 years for 20+ SaaS brands we worked with (including companies like GetResponse, lemlist, Userpilot, etc), and $20m+ generated in revenue for these clients.

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?
